Thank you, Nihon Falcom.

I devoted half of 2025 to playing these games in preparation for the 13th game coming in January, and it needs to be stated: [b]Trails in the Sky 1st Chapter[/b] is a phenomenal remake and should absolutely now be held up as the gold-standard of how to show respect for a beloved JRPG. I did not think I was going to be as sucked into playing this game, given how recent I had gone through the Trails games, but it was very difficult not to fall in love all over again with the coming-of-age journey of Junior Bracers Estelle and Joshua Bright.

For starters, this game is streamlining for an older game done correctly. I was genuinely concerned when I learned that it was following the same gameplay-principles of the Daybreak games, specifically because I wondered if they were going to throw Lore out the window when it came to the advancements in Orbal tech mirroring the advancements in gameplay (something I’ve always appreciated about this franchise). But lo and behold: While the gameplay mirrors the Daybreak games, they managed to tie in a lot of the older systems back in, so it feels decidedly old-school and new-school combined. It’s hard to really go into details if you are new to the franchise, but for those who are in-the-know, this is a beautiful combination of the Sky Trilogy’s gameplay foundations, filtered through the lens of innovations that the Cold Steel and Daybreak games brought forth.

I decided to go into the game right out of the gate with Nightmare difficulty, because after the Cold Steel games, I realized that the difficulty was becoming a joke, to the point that Daybreak 1 and 2’s Nightmare felt like the normal difficulty of the older games. I was pleasantly surprised that 1st Chapter’s Nightmare difficulty might be the most satisfying challenge we have had since the older games without feeling frustrating. You absolutely need to stay on top of your orbment combinations, and you are pushed pretty hard from beginning to end, which made it feel satisfying to finish.

Visuals and audio need to be mentioned: This is, without a doubt, the prettiest looking Trails game to date, and traversing Liberl felt immersive in a way that no other Trails game has felt before. The setting feels lively, the music is absolutely stellar with different renditions you can opt to choose from, and the voice-actors have (thankfully) been given a lot more lines than we’ve had in quite a long time. I really hope that Falcom’s getting the money they need, going forward, because the decline in voiced lines has been a tragedy to witness since the start of the Cold Steel games, and while there are still stretches of time where non-voiced dialogue occurs, 1st Chapter definitely brings [i]enough[/i] lines to feel like we’re getting bang for our buck, for once.

The story beats are the same as the OG, and I must say that a lot of its best moments have thankfully gotten lots of love and attention in a way that the original could not dream to showcase. I’m glad that they went hard on this, because as much as I love the original, it has a very simple premise for a plot, and that can be a tough sell as an introduction to what will very likely be a lot of new players’ first experience with the franchise. For those who are new who will likely ask “Does this story get more interesting later?” I want to just assure you that yes, this franchise features a massive world full of a lot more characters, and if you enjoy the characters in this game’s party, then you are in for a wonderfully long ride if your intent is to now check out the rest of these games.

The important question is: Should you wait for 2nd Chapter’s remake now that we can confirm that it’s happening? That will depend on the type of player you are. Do you NEED the shiny new visuals, English voice-acting, and modern gameplay? Then you should probably wait. What I will say is: If you can put up with the compromises of switching to old visuals, Japanese (until Cold Steel) voice acting, and decidedly oldschool gameplay, my advice is to get started on the rest of the franchise, as I adored the journey and now consider the Trails series to be my absolute favorite JRPG games to date. They have flaws, here and there, but if you can put up with JRPG tropes (comes with the territory of playing them), then you should be able to see the value in this long-running series. 

Please, for the love of Aidios, stop wasting time with Final Fantasy and play these games. That’s an order.

I never played the original Trails in the Sky, so I went into the remake with zero nostalgia—but it honestly won me over pretty fast.

The biggest thing that stood out to me was the characters. Estelle and Joshua have such a fun dynamic, and pretty much everyone you meet adds something to the world. The game takes its time letting you hang out with the cast and get to know them, and it makes the journey feel really personal. Even side characters feel like real people instead of background decorations.

The combat system is also really solid. It’s easy to understand at first, but there’s a lot of depth once you start messing around with positioning, arts, and timing your turns. It hits that perfect “simple but strategic” energy that keeps regular battles from feeling like a slog.

Since I never touched the original version, I can’t compare them, but the remake feels super approachable. The updated visuals and quality-of-life improvements make it way easier to settle into, and it doesn’t feel dated at all.

Overall, the Trails in the Sky 1st remake is a great starting point for anyone wanting to get into the series. The characters carry the whole experience, and the combat is just fun on top of that. Definitely glad I picked it up.

A remake that's really done right.  The original was a great game, no doubt, but it was a PSP game, which means severely limited by technology.  This is a total redo of the game all put into a current day engine with graphics that are really beautiful.  The game's original systems are there, along with some quality of life imporvements so it doesn't feel dated.  So, overall and amazing job from developers that clearly really care and love their games.

There's a few additions of gameplay mechanics that are in line with newer Falcom games that are added that do change the difficulty some, combo attacks and things like that.  Also an upgrade system for gear (nothing too complex) was added.  Overall it serves to make the game a bit easier than the original was (which could be hard in a few places).  Not really a down side in my opinion, but it is a change.

One thing that is a downgrade is the game's translation.  It's a new translation, and it feels like it was done on a shortdeadline.  Some terms that are consistent across other games in the franchise are different here, and it annoys every time you see them.  Also, they consistently mispronounce the name of the nation in the game.  Liberl is a nation, liberal is a political leaning,.  The two are not the same.  You never realized how much they say the name of their nation until you hear it misporonounced every time.  Still, not the end of the world.

Overall it's a great game that's been remade with great care and attention to detail.  Going from pixel graphics on a PSP to the beautiful three dimensional vistas we see here is amazing.  Annoyances with the translation aside, it's a trully great game.

Trails in the sky 1, now I wanna note I have been playing these games for quite a long time now and the Sky series remains my favourite, so how does the remake hold up? It holds up pretty dang well with only one issue I personally see, nothing game breaking but otherwise Sky 1ST Remake was stellar, it kept it's gameplay (as much as it could for 3D) while also adding to how it plays, even adding future games mechanics while enhancing it's original features, with voices included? It makes for the ultimate version of Sky, even if the original still very much has it's charms dood.

Okay full review time! So Sky 1ST for those who have never touched the sky games at all focuses on the daughter and adopted son of Cassius Bright, those being Estelle and Joshua Bright and their quest to become Bracers, Bracers essentially being highly skilled handymen/Jack of all trades/mercenaries? But with a code/rules so to speak, of course as with any game and story it's not quite that simple and so their adventures begin dood!

The gameplay takes from daybreak, you travel through the decently sized parts of Liberl where you encounter various monsters, there you can either fight in live combat (which is better to stun them in than defeat them for an advantageous start) where you can dodge and perform various melee attacks or any time you can press square/X to initiate tactical combat, here is where the real damage lies, here it becomes turn based, you can cast artes (magic) for EP, Crafts (skills) for CP and even S-crafts for 100+ CP dood.

Expanding on combat, for those new to the series again you have a timeline, here it shows who attacks next along with bonus effects that will randomly pop up for you or the enemy, ranging from healing HP/EP/CP, a guaranteed critical or a free instant spell cast, each type of attack and spell you and the enemy have has it's own wait time, on top of that certain skills and effects can delay their times and give you more turns or vice versa, you also have status effects which I feel have been improved in some regard in terms of effect, use and chance rates dood.

Combat also has items and blocking which can be handy in the right situations but not always easy to guess, on top of that there are assist skills from your teammates in game and the ability to escape by simply walking to the edge of the battle area, the exception for that and active combat are bosses or story fights where you are stuck in tactical combat from start to finish dood.

Let's see as for outside of combat we have quests and I find quests in these games have always been super worth it, the people feel like actual unique people in need but more than that for quests besides money you get BP, this increases your bracer rank and nets you some of the best stuff in the game and besides that you also have rewards, a new system that was added in daybreak, for doing various challenges ranging from enemy kills, how you attack them, spells cast, certain items collected ect ect, you get some stellar rewards, including the best armour and shoes in the game and some powerful quartz and accessories dood!

So talking about quartz, for newbies again, these are orbs with various effects that go into what's called an orbament, you use sepith of each colour/element to make them, (these drop from enemies or small amounts from broken objects) effects are all buffs of some sort but also depending on the combination of quartz you equip and strength of them, you can gain various different spells, it was a kind of complex system that has been made visually easier in this and even added all new unique spells to this that never existed before that look fantastic at that dood.

Some more new additions to the game, a map now exists! Which yes never did before, super handy for real, along with that you also have quick travel, this is a mighty boon for the now larger size of the game world, on top of that caves are now a thing, a handy place to grind out a lot of enemies you'll encounter per area, you also have costumes now too, there's some fun free ones to go with some of the DLC ones too as well as a bunch of costume accessories too and finally you have three track types to choose from! The original games OST to go classic, modern version for this game or arranged! Falcom and their music at their best I swear dood.

Okay last thing to talk about, I do feel how damage calculation is done is kind of poorly, I think it's acceptable mind you but the issue is that it makes buff skills and spells suffer, it's one of those you do x amount of damage at 100 ATK vs 100 DEF but then it doesn't really change until you reach 200 ATK VS 100 DEF (that's an example mind you nit accurate to the games numbers) which is fiine but it means that buffs are basically just there to push your stats up if you are under-equipped for some reason to do not pitiful damage or the like, frankly they should have kept it like in cold steel and make it do a buffed % of what damage you do instead, as it stands you're just wasting turns buffing sadly dood.

And that's it really, the game adds so many great things, including icons on maps I forgot to mention making things easier to find than ever, there's nothing not to love about the game, Falcom did an outstanding job in making one of their most loved games even better and showing other devs how a real remake is done, thank you for reading and I hope you enjoy the game as much as I have dood ^-^

For new players: Welcome! No longer do you need to wonder "What Trails game should I start with first?" as this is the answer, full stop. This is a full 3D remake of the original Trails in the Sky released over 11 years ago on Steam, complete with all modern Trails features and QoL improvements such as: real time combat (for non-boss encounters), little markers indicating when NPCs do or do not have new dialog to read, fast travel, better tuned difficulty settings, and more. [Do be aware if real time combat is a major draw, it is only present in the Daybreak games, and anything released after; the 2D games and Cold Steel are 100% turn-based]

Trails in the Sky 1st Chapter focuses on the adventures of Estelle and Joshua Bright as they travel across Liberl to find out what happened to their father as well as resolving any local incidents that may crop up in each of the 5 major cities along the way. Fight in real time to stun enemies and whittle down their HP before finishing them off in turn-based combat (or wipe them out with only real time if you prefer). Boss and mini-boss fights are turn-based only, so don't slack off on those skills.

Outside of combat, you have dialog and characters aplenty. One of the very few gripes I have is that not all major characters are voiced all the time. This is on par with practically every Trails release (and Falcom release in general), but voices are present more often than they are not. You'll quickly feel at home with each character, their personality, and their interactions with each other and the world at large. And the NPCs? They're all named, some of them have their own mini-storylines that go along as your own does, and you might even see them later in the game elsewhere, or even in a future game altogether!

For anyone that is a fan of turn-based gameplay, massive lore and world building, intimate character connections, or story-driven gameplay, Trails in the Sky 1st Chapter is an easy buy. And the best thing about coming in late? There are plenty of more games available RIGHT NOW to keep the ride going before you ever have to join the rest of us in having to wait for the next release.

Trails in the Sky 1st Chapter is a story-driven JRPG that prioritizes narrative depth and character development over spectacle. It follows Estelle and Joshua as they join the Bracer Guild, an organization dedicated to helping people through contract work. While the game includes exploration and combat, its true strength lies in its world-building.

The game takes its time to introduce characters, NPCs, and locations. This creates a sense of community and realism rarely seen in video games. For example, after helping local farmers, you do not simply move on — you are invited to stay for dinner and even sleep overnight including additional dialogue. Or Estelle, who first asks if the maiden and wife (two minor side characters) are okay after an incident in the mayor's office. By the way, the game has a lot of German names for its NPCs and locations. Side quests also contribute to world-building by tying into local issues. Furthermore, NPCs react to current events and the presence of recurring NPC characters gives the impression that the world is alive, with each NPC following their own goals. However, pacing slows noticeably in Chapter 2, pushing the main story into the background until the final chapter. 

The in-game cutscenes are well-done. Dialogue feels natural and grounded, supported by thoughtful camera work and character animations during cutscenes. The dialogue is generally well written, though there are occasional lines that feel a bit rough. The game maintains a mostly serious tone, with occasional lighthearted moments. Some of them edge into borderline silly JRPG territory. For example, occasional naughty references that feel a bit out of place, and exaggerated anime facial expressions using “> <” symbols for the eyes.

What makes the narrative stand out is its careful buildup. Unlike many games where major events happen abruptly, Trails in the Sky introduces plot points gradually, allowing players to connect with the world and its inhabitants first. The game creates realistic relationships between people, where everyone knows everyone, including gossip. The overall tone is charming and positive, with most characters being polite and likable. Especially the contrast between the two main protagonists is fun to watch. 

Exploration is also fun thanks to hidden chests and small rewards off the main path. Unfortunately, the level design is disappointing: areas are linear and tunnel-like, with heavy asset reuse and few points of interest. Most levels consist of simple paths lined with trees and grass, lacking variety or memorable landmarks. At least backtracking is minimal, and fast travel between major landmarks is available. Most side quests also follow a simple, linear structure, often boiling down to errands with no surprises or sub-events. Moreover, there are "treasure dungeons" that can be looted by simply running past enemies, which can feel underwhelming. 

Combat offers an unusual mix of real-time and turn-based systems. Real-time battles allow quick disposal of weak enemies but feel like button-mashing. Turn-based combat is more as spells (Artes) and abilities are unlocked which add more complexity in terms of elemental damage and status effects. Each character has separate energy pools for spells and abilities, though these feel overly generous on normal difficulty. In turn based-combat, positioning matters: abilities have different AoE shapes, and some attacks from the side or back deal extra damage. However, the third-person perspective makes battlefield overview less practical. Furthermore, enemies can be stunned by repeated attacks, triggering automated team combos.

Each spell and ability is accompanied by a nice animation. However, these animations are rather long and repetitive, which is why they quickly become tedious. For this reason, I mostly used high-speed mode during combat (although you can skip combat animations, I was too lazy to press the skip button each time). Elemental weaknesses encourage you to equip diverse spells, but despite a decent variety of enemies, most encounters feel similar on normal difficulty. Occasional boss fights add some variety. I wish the main characters played more differently — unique abilities aside, shared spell pools make them feel too similar.

Player progression is slow and incremental. The orbment system let you unlock slots and put colored orbs into the slots to unlock spells and stat bonuses. It is neat system but also difficult to manage since you must consider different colors and connected paths. Combining different colored orbs on a path unlocks new spells, allowing you to customize and specialize your characters. Additionally, necklaces allow you to further refine your builds by granting specific stat bonuses and/or immunities. You will also find one or two new weapons in each chapter that simply have better stats than the previous ones. Furthermore, equipment items and orbs can be upgraded once by spending resources collected through combat and exploration. There is also a basic cooking system. As with most JRPGs, I mostly ignored it, except for the rewards given for cooking a meal for the first time. Besides that, there is an achievement system that provides small bonuses for various tasks, most of which you will eventually achieve by playing the game, such as cooking five meals or casting X different spells. 

I like the game's menus. They are well-designed and with good comparison screens during shopping. A minor quibble are the different font sizes which can feel inconsistent at times. I also find the rarely used green font color a bit unfitting.

Visually, the game is bright and colorful, reminding me of Tales of Zestiria. I like the character and costume designs, particularly those of the main characters and NPCs. However, some minor NPCs look too similar due to asset reuse. Unfortunately, the environments often feel uninspired and repetitive because of the heavy reuse of assets, which is further exacerbated by the simple level design. Towns are more appealing, but most NPCs remain static, and interior design lacks creativity. Transitions between indoor and outdoor areas feel abrupt like running through a portal, but at least load times are fast. By the way, I love it when a game loads the last save automatically at startup, skipping the main menu entirely.

While not the most complex, the music is very good and provides a cozy, positive vibe. The tracks are repeated often due to their limited number, but that didn't bother me. I found "Feelings Soar with the Wind" to be particularly catchy. The voice acting is good as well. I especially liked Joshua's voice, though Estelle's voice acting sometimes sounds a bit inconsistent. Unfortunately, the English lip-syncing is often off, and not all dialogue is voiced. I find it particularly odd that many scenes mix voiced and unvoiced lines, with the main characters being unvoiced.

All in all, Trails in the Sky 1st Chapter is a charming JRPG with a character-driven narrative and rich world-building. Its slow storytelling, simple level design, and modest presentation may not appeal to all players, but those who value character-driven storytelling and interconnected worlds will find it rewarding. The combat, crafting, and progression systems are good and functional, although I would not play the game just because of them, as I miss some additional depth. I am especially not convinced of splitting combat into two systems (real-time and turn-based). Turn-based combat with positioning in a third person perspective is not my favorite either. Still, battles are engaging enough to bridge story segments, and exploration, while basic, offers small rewards to maintain a steady sense of dopamine release. Overall, I enjoyed my journey with Estelle and Joshua and cannot wait for it to continue.

[h1]🌶️Overall rating: 5/5🌶️[/h1]
As someone who played the OG, this game simply amazed me with every turn; there was nothing that I felt was better in the original. Even the charming sprites were kept in the loading screens. I simply had no complaints about it. I am looking forward to the next one and you bet I'm gonna drop money on it immediately.

[h3]🌶️Gameplay🌶️[/h3]
The mix between turn-based and overworld was a breath of fresh air. Fight, run, or git gud with dodging; you can do it all. While I eventually went into turn-based quicker as we got stronger stats, it was really helpful to have early game.

The game also gets much easier as your progress. Starting from Chapter 2, I had to swap to Nightmare mode as the battles were too easy for me.

The only issue I had with combat was that I had no idea if we managed to steal the buffs from enemies or not. Sometimes you end up not reacting fast enough to attempt to steal it again because you wanted to 'wait and see'.

In terms of missable items, there were definitely some secrets, but since everything is marked you won't miss too much as long as you make sure to go through everything. Although, I did end up [spoiler] missing a recipe as I forgot to read the books[/spoiler], but that's honestly on me lol.

[h3]🌶️Story🌶️[/h3]
The story was really solid, especially near the end. As someone who played the OG I thought I was ready for the ending. I wasn't. It was super emotional, especially with the music, and I couldn't help but cry.

I really liked how the characters were written and could really relate to Estelle. They grew on me so much and [spoiler]Joshua leaving[/spoiler] hit me even harder. I can't wait for the continuation.

I loved how this game struck a balance between setting up for the next game and also having enough hard hitting story points in the current one.

[h3]🌶️Music and Voice Acting🌶️[/h3]
The music is probably my favourite part of the game. The remixed versions were really done well, and during the emotional scenes I was literally moved to tears. You even had the option to use the OG music, which was a really nice touch.

For the voice acting, I played it in English, and the English voice actors were phenomonal. There wasn't a single time I felt that a character was 'off', except for [spoiler]Tita[/spoiler], who I expected to be higher pitched, not that it was bad.

[h3]🌶️Graphics and Optimization🌶️[/h3]
This game runs amazingly. I played and streamed everything on medium, and my OBS simply purred like a kitchen. It doesn't have the most amazing graphics, but it was beautiful enough for me. I loved the art style, the effects, and even the environment. Truly a glow up from the OG.

1st Chapter is everything a remake should aspire to be. More than just a simple retread of what came before with prettier graphics, it takes full advantage of the capabilities of modern hardware. I am primarily writing this review to go over how the game improves over the original.  

Graphically, the game is a feast for the eyes. Rather than chase the bottomless rabbit hole of realism, Falcom tastefully rendered the game in a cell-shaded anime style. It runs perfectly on lower-end hardware (as low as the Switch!) and still makes you stop to admire everything around you every now and then. Grass is rendered in such a lush, verdant green, it makes you want to step through the screen and spend the afternoon laying in it without a care in the world. I have to mention the evenings; skies are a beautiful golden hue that make the whole environment shine in its luster. Combat and action cutscenes are a total thrill to watch. Characters are lovingly animated and I found myself slowing down to watch animations like Joshua's Flicker the thousandth time I saw it.

The characters are by far the biggest beneficiaries of the remake. Falcom took full advantage of the presentation capabilities of full 3D and brought their cast to life. Major story moments are shot in such a way you feel you're watching an anime; characters have different expressions and poses and actions for each scene, there's never a moment of standing around and reading of paragraphs of dialogue at each other. The (Japanese) voice acting is excellent and captures the intended emotions of each scene perfectly. These changes to the presentation make what was, admittedly, a game that was slow-paced to the point of boredom at points, into an engaging experience from start to finish you never want to take a break from.

Combat is vastly improved with additions from later games in the series, such as Cold Steel's brave attacks and character links. These additions spice up even routine enemy battles and give the player a fuller toolkit of options for each potential situation. But I will say that the game's difficulty wasn't increased enough to compensate for all the new options in the player's arsenal. It's very easy to overwhelm enemies with a full 5-BP burst attack or be saved from a tricky situation with a character's bond-link action such as auto-revives.  But the original quartz system remains, where you have to carefully balance what stats you want your characters to have with what arts you wish to unlock. The real-time combat is a fun way to take out trash mobs out in the overworld, but it is basic compared to Falcom's real action games like YS VIII and is primarily intended as a way to soften up monsters before finishing them off in the traditional turn-based combat mode.

The story remains the same as the original. It is a slow burn, meant to build up and explore the Kingdom of Liberl before the REAL action starts in the 2nd Chapter. The English localization has changed from the original XSEED release, while there is much controversy over this change (and the liberties XSEED took in their localization), I will say the dialogue was fine and was not "flat" as some may complain. All of the notes hit, in moments of both tragedy and comedy. Overall, it reads as a more faithful translation of the Japanese, and yes, that means no Joss Whedon/MCU-esque quips every other line of dialogue. But strangely the new localization took liberties in places XSEED didn't, but not to the same degree as XSEED. There are no character derailments or exaggerations like XSEED's Estelle. 

The soundtrack is a beautiful orchestrated version of the original tracks, and sounds so faithful throughout most of the game you have to listen to the tracks one after the other to tell the difference. There are no embarrassments like in the EVO arranged version of the original's soundtrack. Which, by the way, is an option you can choose along with the original and the full remake's OST. Silver Will sounds more bone-chilling and adrenaline-inducing than ever.

I am almost 60 hours into the game, on chapter 3 of 4, and there are absolutely no stakes what so ever. You are literally traveling from town to town doing random odd jobs for people. Like, there are monsters in my garden can you make them go away? I lost the keys to my warehouse, can you find them? A light went out on the side of the road, can you fix it? I need some mushrooms for my soup, can you find me some? I am not even joking.
No big bad guy trying to take over the world, or summon a demon from a nether plan. No mana tree dying inviting monsters into the world, nothing. 
I read the game picks up, but I can't recommend someone buy this game to spend 60 hours doing menial jobs where nothing important is going on at all. Only reason I am not dropping the game right here is because I already put so much time in. 
If you like the over the top, epic level story from games like the Tales series, Mana series, Final Fantasy, YS, so on, this game does not have it. 
Everything else is top notch.

This game was obviously written before ChatGPT existed, but it kind of feels like it was at times with how much nothing happens
Feels cheap and soulless against the original. Will be refunding
